bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kîtahtawê êh-mihcêticik ayîsiyiniwak , êkwah ôpwâsîmôwak , êkwah nahkawiyiniwak . Once upon a time there were many of the people, and also of the Assiniboine Sioux and of the Salteaux.
êkos îsi mihcêtiwak , iskwêwak , awâsisak ê-wîcihiwêcik , tâpiskôc êh-pimipicicik . They were numerous, for they had their women and children with them, as they all trekked together.
kîtahtawê êtokê nisto opwâsîmôwak oskinîkiwak ê-spwêhtêcik , ê-wih-kakwê-wâpamâcik iyahciyiniwah . Then at one time three Assiniboine youths left the band, to try to get sight of Blackfoot.
ômis îsiyihkâtêw êwakoh : êh-ntawâhtâcik isiyîhkâtêw . This is called as follows: they went on a reconnaissance, it is called.

ôk ôskinîkiwak kâ-nisticik , kîtahtawê mân êh-sâkêwêcik , kâ-wâpamâcik pêyak ayahciyiniwah , pêyak misatimwa ; As those three youths surmounted one hill after the other, presently they saw a single Blackfoot and one horse;
êh-kitâpamâcik , ês ôma êh-wiyinihtâkêyit . when they observed him, it appeared that he was dressing a carcass.
êkwah êyakoni nâciyôstawêwak ôk ôskinîkiwak , kisiwâk êy-osâpamâcik . Then those youths crept up to him, and watched him from close by.
atimapiyiwa , ê-wiyinihtâkêyit , ê-mosêskatêyit , êh-kîsopwêyik . He was sitting with his back turned, dressing his game, and he wore scant clothes, for it was a hot day.
môskîstawêwak . [no translation]

iyikohk ê-môsihikocik , kêkâc êh-otihtâcik , pâsici-kwâskohtiw aw ayahciyiniw omostosoma , êh-kwêskipayihot , âsay ôhi pêyak oskinîkiwah kâ-tahkamikot . When he perceived their presence, as they were almost upon him, the Blackfoot jumped over his buffalo-carcass and turned to face them, but already one of the youths had stabbed him.
êkos êh-otihtinikot , êh-nipahikot , ôma ostikwân ê-pahkwêkisamiyit . So they seized him and killed him, and cut the scalp from his head.
misatimwah min ôhi otinêwak , mîn opâskisikaniyiw , mîna otayôwinisiyiwa . And they took also his horse and his gun and his clothes.
êkosi namoy âwiya kotakah wâpamêwak ôk ôskinîkiwak . The youths saw no one else.
namoya kiskêyimêwak tântê êy-ohtohtêt aw âyahciyiniw . They did not know from where that Blackfoot had come.
êkosi kîwêpahtâwak ôk ôskinîkiwak , ê-wih-ntaw-âcimocik ôh êh-nipahâcik ayahciyiniwah . So those youths gallopped back, to go tell of how they had slain that Blackfoot.

tâpwê itah êh-wâpamâcik ayîsiyiniwa owîcêwâkaniwâwa , êkotah takohtêwak , êh-âcimocik êh-pêyakowit ayahciyiniwah êh-nipahâcik . They went to where they saw the people of their band, and told of how they had slain a lone Blackfoot.

seg.q: namoya nikiskêyihtên tântê êy-ohtohtêt aw âyahciyiniw kâ-nipahiht .
seg.gloss: “I do not know from where he came, that Blackfoot who has been killed.”
seg.note: LB: I suspect that there is a tabu, - except for certain special circumstances, cf. below in this story, - against saying, “whome I (or we) have killed.” Certainly some of my Plains Cree friends have killed their man, but I have never heard them, even in telling of war, mention such a fact.

p.seg: êkosi sipwêhtêwak kahkiyaw ôk âyîsiyiniwak . So all those people set out.
êh-otâkosiniyik otihtêwak ôh âyahciyiniwah , êh-wâ-wâpamâcik ; Toward evening they came to that Blackfoot and examined him;
êkwah namoya kiskêyihtamok tântê êh-wîkiyit . and they did not know where his camp had been.

ômisih itwêwak :
ka-kiskêyimânawak tântê wîkitwâwi ; They said, “We shall know where they have their camp;

seg.gloss: we shall see them when they come to look for this man.”

p.seg: tahkih asawâpiwak , itah êh-wâyahcâyik êh-ayâcik ôki nêhiyawak . They kept a continuous look-out, and the Cree stayed in a hollow of the land.
nam âwiya wâpamêwak . they saw no one.
piyis tipiskâw . At last it was night.
êkotah kapêsiwak . They camped there.
êh-wâpahk , âtah êh-nanâtawâpicik , nama kêkway wâpahtamok . When day came, although they kept on the watch, they saw nothing.

kîtahtawê omis îtwêwak ôki nêhiyawak :
mahtih nîswayak t-êspayiwak oskinîkiwak ; Presently the Cree said, “Let young men ride off in two directions;
êh-mîhkawikiyit ta-têhtapiwak , itwêwak . let them ride fast horses.”
tâpwê awihâwak ê-mîhkawikiyit misatimwa . Accordingly they were lent fast horses.
pêyak natimîhk isih ispayiw , pêyak âpihtâ-kîsikâhk itêhkêy isih . One rode west, and one in the direction of noon.

piyisk wâhyawês ê-ispatinâyik ê-sâkêwêt , êkotah êh-ay-apit , ê-nanâtawâpit , kîtahtawê kâ-pê-sâkêwê-têhtapiyit pêyak ayîsiyiniwah . Presently, as he came out over a hill a little ways off, as he stopped there apd looked about, a Blackfoot came riding into view.
piyisk kotakah mîna ; piyisk ati-mihcêtiyiwa , êkwah êh-ntonâht awa kâ-nipahiht ayahciyiniw . Soon another; soon there were many of them, looking for the Blackfoot who had been slain.
êkwah pê-môskîstâk awa nêhiyaw . Then they came to attack that Cree.
ômis îsiyîhkâsôw awa nêhiyaw : cacwâsin isiyîhkâsôw . This was the Cree's name: Tchatchiwasin was his name.
êkosi têhtapiw , êh-tapasît . So he mounted his horse and fled.
nisihk iyâpasâpamâcih , pôtih mihcêtiyiwa , nâh-nâway êh-pâpayiyit . When in a leisurely way he looked behind him, he saw that they were many, riding after him one behind the other.
pêyak wâhyaw pê-nakasiwêyiwa , êh-wâpiskisiyit êh-têhtapiyit . One had far outdistanced the rest; he rode a white horse.
namoya sôhkih wîh-tapasîw , êh-kiskêyihtahk êh-mîhkawikiyit ôhih kâ-têhtapit . The Cree did not intend to flee fast, for he knew that his mount was fleet.
tahkih nah-iyikohk pâpayiyiwa . They kept coming toward him, always at about the same distance.
kîtahtawê kâ-pêtisâpamikot owîcêwâkanah . Presently his people saw him coming.
wawêyîwak nêhiyawak , kâ-mîhkawikiyit otêmiwâwa êyakoni êh-têhtapicik . The Cree made ready, mounting their swiftest horses.
kisiwâk êkwah pê-askôk ôh îyahciyiniwah , mâka namoya sôhki êh-tapasît . and now the Blackfoot were coming close behind him, but he did not flee fast.

kiskêyihtam kisiwâk êh-ayâyit owîcêwâkanah ,
namoya nika-kîh-atimik misawâc , êh-itêyihtahk . He knew that his companions were near, and thought, “In any case they will not be able to catch me in time.”
mwêhc êkwah êh-otihtahk ôm ê-osêhcâyik , êkotah k-âyâyit owîcêwâkanah , êkoyikohk kisiwâk êkwah askôk . By the time he reached the hill where his people were, they were close upon him.
kîtahtawê ka-pê-sâkêwêpayiyit êkwah owîcêwâkana . Then suddenly out into view came his companions.
âsay ôk îyahciyiniwak otêmiwâwa nayawapiyiwa . By this time the Blackfoots' horses were tired.

êh-wâwinipitâcik , êh-tapasîcik ôk îyahciyiniwak , awa wâpastimwa kâ-têhtapit êh-wâwinipitât otêma , êh-tapasît , âsay kisiwâk askôk nêhiyawa . When they pulled them round, to flee, and when the one who rode the white horse pulled it round to run away, the Cree were already close upon him. LB on {êh-wâwinipitâcik}: This word, as here recorded, may show the normal form of what I have generally taken to be {wâyôniw}: “he turns back.” If so, it is strange that I seem never to have heard the latter as *{wâwinîw}.
êh-pasastêhwât otêma , kâ-pahkisiniyit . When he struck his horse with the quirt, it fell.
nîhcipayiw aw âyahciyiniw . The Blackfoot was thrown.
ê-wîh-waniskât , kâ-tawikipayihikot misatimwa nêhiyawa êh-têhtapiyit . When he tried to get up, the Crees' horses trampled him.
mîna ê-wîh-waniskât , âsay otêhtinik nêhiyawa , êh-tah-tahkamikot , ê-npahikot . When again he tried to get up, the Cree were already upon him, and killed him with knife-thrusts.

êkotah ôhci êkwah , nâh-nâway êh-atih-nipahihcik iyahciyiniwak , piyis mihcêt nipahâwak . From then on, as they overtook and killed one alter the other of the Blackfoot, in the end they had slain many of them.
ayis nayawapiyiwa otêmiwâwa . For the Blackfoots' horses were tired.
ôki piko wâhyaw kâ-kîh-nakatihcik ayahciyiniwak , êyakonik piko takohtêwak wîkiwâhk . Only those of the Blackfoot who had been left far behind, only they reached their camp.
êyakonik âcimowak êh-mihcêtiyit nêhiyawa , mîna âsay mihcêt êh-nipahihcik ayahciyiniwak . They told of how the Cree were numerous and that already many Blackfoot had been slain.

êkosi itah êh-tahtakwahcâk , êkotah kahkiyaw itohtêwak , êh-wâtihkêcik , iskwêwak mîna wâsakâm êh-apahkwêcik wîkiwâwah ohci , pêyak piko mîkiwâhp êy-osîhtâcik , êkotah awâsisak iskwêwak êy-asiwasocik . Then they all went to a flat place in the land and dug a trench, and the women sheltered it all round with covering from their tipis, so as to make one great tent, into which the women and children were placed.
piyis kahkiyaw takohtêwak , tahtoh êkâ ê-npahihcik ok êyahciyiniwak . Soon all the Blackfoot had come there, as many as had not been killed.

êkwah wîhkwêskawêwak itah , êkwah êh-nôtinitocik , kahkiyaw êh-takohtêcik ôki nêhiyawak mina opwâsîmôwak mîna nahkawiyiniwak . Then they surrounded them there, and they fought, all the Cree and Assiniboine and Salteaux having come there.

pêyak opwâsimôw , mistah êh-miyosit oskinîkiw , sihkosiwayânah êh-kikamoyit oskotâkâhk mîna otâsihk , kahkiyaw êh-mîkisiwiyikih otâyôwinisah , mîna otastotin sihkosiwayânah êh-kikamôwit , êskanah êh-kikamôwit otastotinihk , êyako êkotah êh-ayât om êh-nôtinitôwiht , namoya nôtinikêw , êh-pêhât ôhtâwiya , câpîhcikanis êh-tahkonahk , A certain Assiniboine, a very handsome youth, with weaselskins on his coat and on his breeches, with beads on all his clothes, and weaselskins also on his toque, and horns, beside, on his headgear, he, staying tight close to the fight, took yet no active part in it, for he was awaiting his father, holding in hand a lance and a tomahawk and a bowie knife;

êkwah cîkahikani-pakamâkan êh-tahkonahk , êkwah napakihkomân , âsay nîso êh-pê-tahkamât câpîhcikanis ohci ayahciyiniwah , êkwah pêyak êh-cîkahwât ôm ôhci ocîkahikanis , êkosi nisto êh-nipahât , ostikwâniyiwah ôhi pâh-pâhkih êh-pahkwêkisamwât ,
pitah nka-miyâw nôhtâwiy , êh-itêyihtahk , otêmiyiwa nîso êh-otinât mîna . with his lance he had already transfixed two Blackfoot on the way hither, and had tomahawked one, so that he had slain three: taking a part of each one's scalp, in the thought, “Later I shall give them to my father,” and taking also two of their horses. LB: A typical Central Algonquian sentence, such as for obvious reasons is not often obtained in dictation or in the laborious process fo syllabic writing. In length and suppleness of subordination it resembled earlier Indo-European, e.g. Latin.
piyis mihcêtiyiwa owîcêwâkana , êh-takohtêyit . Soon many of his companions had arrived.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamât ôhtâwiya itah êh-apit êh-pêy-itohtêyit . Presently he saw his father coming to where he sat.

seg.gloss: “Oh, two I stabbed on the way;
I took their horses; and I took their heads.”
seg.note: LB on {ostikwâniwâwa}: “Head” for “scalp”, as often; I do not know whether this locution dates back to the antecedents of the custom.

p.seg: ôhi êyakoni ostikwâniyiwa wâpahtam awa kisêyiniw . The old man looked at the scalps.

êkwah pêyak ôma ohci nipê-cîkahwâw , itêw ôhtâwiya
êkosi nisto nnipahâwak , itêw . “And one with this I felled as I came,” he told his father; “So that I have killed three,” he told him.
hay hay hay ! itwêw awa kisêyiniw ; “Splendid!” cried the old man;
êkosi , nikosis , miywâsin êh-tôtaman , êh-miyosiyin , itêw . “That is the right way to do, since you are handsome,” he told him.
êkos êkotah ay-apiw , pit êh-pîhtwât awa kisêyiniw . Then the old man sat there a while and smoked.

ê-kîh-pîhtwât ,
mahtih , nikosis , pêtâh kimôhkomân . When he had smoked, “Come, Son, give me your knife.”
otinam aw oskinîkiw , êh-miyât ôhtâwiya . The youth drew it and gave it to his father.
tah-tâsaham oma môhkomân . He whetted the knife.

seg.gloss: “There, my son, even this is your knife.
Such game as the Blackfoot is not seen every day;

p.seg: mostos pikoh tahto-kîsikâw kâ-wâpamiht , itêw . it is only the buffalo is seen every day,” he told him.
kah ! itwêw oskinîkiw . “I hear what you say!” said the youth.
êkosi pasikôw , itêh kâ-nôtinitôwiht êh-itohtêt aw ôskinîkiw . Accordingly he rose to his feet, the youth, and went to the fight.
piyisk takohtêw . Soon he arrived there.
êkwah êh-kitâpamât , nam âwiya wâpamêw ayahciyiniwah . Then when he looked to see them, he saw none of the Blackfoot.
mâka âsay wâh-wâpamêw nêhiyawa , cîk êkotê ê-pimisiniyit , ê-nipahimiht . But already he saw Cree lying near by, Cree who had been slain.
êkot êspahtâw , ê-kwâh-kwâskwêpayihot awa kâ-miyosit oskinîkiw . To that place ran the handsome youth, leaping high as he ran.
cîkih ayahciyiniwah k-âyâyit , êkotah nahapipayihôw . Close to where the Blackfoot were, he flung himself into a crouching position.
mayaw êh-nahapit , pâskisok ayahciyiniwah . As soon as he had squatted down, the Blackfoot shot at him.
kîpiwêpahok , êh-nipahikot . He was hit headlong, and killed.
âsay wîhtamawâw awa kisêyiniw . Already the old man was being told.
ômisih isiyîhkâsôw : mistikwaskihk isiyîhkâsôw awa ôkosisah kâ-miyosiyit . his was his name: Wooden-Drum was the name of him whose son was so handsome.
wêy ! itwêw . “What is it?” he asked.
kikosis nipahâw ! itêw . “Your son has been killed!” he was told.
kah ! itwêw . “I hear!” he answered.
itohtêw . He went there.
êh-itâpit , kâ-wâpamât okosisah ê-pimisiniyit . When he looked, he saw his son lying there.
itohtêw , êh-ispahtât . He went there, running.
otihtêw okosisah , cîki ayahciyiniwah itah êh-ayâyit . He reached his son, close by to where the Blackfoot were.
otinam okosisah otastotiniyiw , ê-postastotinêt . He took his son's headgear and placed it on his own head.

êh-kîsi-postastotinêt , êkwah ôma cîkahikanis êh-otinahk , âta êh-pâh-pâskisoht , âhci pikoh apiw , êh-kwêskapit , êh-is-ôhtiskawapit itêh k-ôh-pâskisoht . Having put on the headgear, he took the tomahawk, and though he was being fired at, yet he stayed sitting there, turning so as to face the fire.
sâsakiciwêpahwâw , êh-nipahiht . He was felled backward and killed.
âsay osîma têpwâtimâwa . Already the cry came to his younger brother.
mistanikocâsah-kâ-pimwât , kistês nipahâw ! itimâwa osîma . “Shoots-the-Gopher, your elder brother has been killed!” his brother was told.
êkosi awa êkotêh itohtêw . Then he too went there.
êh-itâpit , pôtih kâ-wâpamât ostêsah êkwah okosisah êh-nipahimiht . When he looked that way, there he saw his brother and his brother's son lying slain.
pasikôw , êh-itohtêt , êh-ati-wayacâwît . He rose to his feet and went there, breaking into a run.
êh-âta-pâskisoht , piyisk otihtêw . Although he was fired at, he went there.
ostêsah otinam ôma cîkahikanis , ê-môskîstawât ayahciyiniwah . He took the tomahawk from his brother, and made for the Blackfoot.
pîhtokêw wîkiyihk , êh-cîkahwât nîso ayahciyiniwah . He entered their camp and felled two Blackfoot.
hâw , nitôtêmitik , kakwêh-otinihk nikosis têpiyâhk , kiyâm nistês êkotê ka-pimisin , itwêw . So now, friends, try to take up my son's body at least. Let my brother's lie there,” he said.
tâpwê moskîstawêwak oskinîkiwak . Accordingly, the young men made for them.
ât êh-pâskisohcik , otihtêwak ôhi kâ-miyosiyit oskinîkiwa . Although they were shot at, they reached the handsome youth.
otinêwak , ê-kospohtahâcik . They took him up and carried him off.
takohtahêwak owîcêwâkaniwâwa t êh-ayâyit . They brought him to where their comrades were.
êkosi âhci pikoh êh-nôtinâcik , êh-pâskiswâcik . Then they kept on fighting the enemy, and shooting at them.

êkwah ôki nêhiyawak cîki ê-pimisihkik , êh-mâtâposihkik êwakonik êh-nâpêhkâsocik , ositiwâhk êkotêh âtiht êh-ayâyit owîcêwâkaniwâwa , And where the Cree were lying near there, as the braves lay in a row, with some of their comrades close at their feet,

ôki nîkân kâ-pimisihkik , kâh-ta-tasinahkwâwi , tapâhtsikwêyiwak , ôki kotakak êh-tasinahkik , iyahciyiniwah êh-pâ-pâskiswâcik . then, whenever those who lay in the front rank had fired, they would duck their heads, and the others would fire, sending a volley at the Blackfoot.

kîtahtawê awa pêyak nêhiyaw otâhk k-âpit , ositiyihk isi oskinîkiwa , mwêhcih ê-wîh-tasinahk , k-ôhpiskwêyiyit oskinîkiwa owîcêwâkana . Then at one time just as a certain Cree in the rear rank was about to fire, the youth, his comrade, who lay by his feet, raised his head.
ostikwâniyihk pistahwêw oskinîkiwa ; nipahêw . Thus accidentally he shot the youth in the head and killed him.
pakwâtam êh-pistahwât otôtêma . He was grieved at having shot his friend.

ômis îtwêw :
hahahêy , tâpwê nipakwâtên êh-pistahowêyân ! itwêw , êh-pasikôt , êkotah êh-ntawi-nahapit ôh ôskinîkiwa kâ-nipahât . Thus he spoke: “Alas, truly I am grieved at having made a fatal error!” he cried, rising to his feet, and went and sat by the youth he had killed.
namwâc kinwêsk apiw âsay ostikwânihk êh-tawahokot iyahciyiniwah ; kîpiwêpahok . He had not been there long, before the Blackfoot sent a bullet through his head; he fell hurtling.
êkosi otinâw , âkawâyihk êh-itohtahiht awa mîna oskinîkiw . So he was taken up and brought to a sheltered spot, and the body of the youth as well.
âhci pikoh yêhyêw awa ayahciyiniwah ostikwânihk kâ-pâskisokot . He who had been shot in the head by the Blackfoot was still breathing.
ncawâc nipiy itah êh-ayâyik , êkotah itohtahâw , êkotah êh-pimisihk , êh-akwanahiht wâpowayân . He was taken to where there was water, and there he lay, covered with a blanket.
êkos îsi ohpimê itohtêwak ôk âyîsiyiniwak , omê êh-nôtinitocik kêyâpic . Then the people went off, to fight again. LB on {omê}: Probably error for {ôma}.
kîtahtawê kâwaniskât awa nipîhk kâ-pimisimiht , êh-pê-pasikôt , Then presently he arose who had been laid by the water's edge;

êh-takohtêt otôtêma itah êh-ayâyit , êkota êh-nahapit ,
oskinîkitik , oyaskinahihk ! êh-itwêt ; he rose to his feet and walked over to his companions, and sat down there, saying, “Young men, fill a pipe.
nka-pîhtwân , êh-itwêt . Let me smoke.”

tâpwê êh-kitâpamâcik ôhi ostikwâniyihk kâ-kîh-pâskisomiht , namwâc ihtakoniyiw ôm itah kâ-kî-pâskisomiht . Truly, when they looked at him who had been shot in the head, not a trace was there of the bullet-wound.
êh-manitôwit awa nâpêw , êh-nanâtawihisot , êkosi nama takoniyiw om îtah kâ-pâskisoht . Because that man had manitou power and had cured himself, there was no trace of the gunshot-wound.
pimâtisiw êwakoh nahkawiyiniw . That Salteau lived.
piyis wîpac pôyôwak . Soon after that they ceased fighting.
wiyawâw mîna mihcêt nipahikwak . and on their side, too, many had been slain.
êkosi pê-kîwêwak ôkih nêhiyawak , êh-miyawâtahkik , ê-miywêyihtahkik , mihcêt êh-nipahâcik ayahciyiniwah . Then the Cree went home, celebrating their joy at having killed many Blackfoot.
piyis takosinwak wîkiwâhk ôki nêhiyawak . In time those Cree arrived at their camp.
êkoyikohk êh-iskwâk êwako âcimowin . This is the end of the story.
